[[Melek Taus]] ({{lang|fa|ÙÙÙ Ø·Ø§ÙÙØ³}} - Kurdish TawÃ»sÃª Melek), the '''Peacock Angel''', is the [[Yazidi]] name for the central figure of their faith. After he repented, he wept for 7,000 years, his tears filling seven jars, which then quenched the fires of [[hell]]. In art and sculpture, TawÃ»sÃª Melek is depicted as a peacock. â
[[Image:1956_NBC_logo.svgâ|thumb|left|200px|John J. Graham's early NBC peacock design]]
  â
[[Image:NBC_logo.svg|thumb|right|180px|[[NBC]]'s current stylized peacock logo]]
 
In 1956, John J. Graham created an abstraction of an eleven-feathered [[peacock logo]] for American broadcaster [[NBC]]. This brightly hued peacock was adopted due to the increase in color programming. NBC's first color broadcasts showed only a still frame of the colorful peacock. The emblem made its first on-air appearance on May 22, 1956.<ref>The New York Times Encyclopedia of Television by Les Brown (Times Books, a division of Quadrangle/The New York Times Book Company, Inc., 1977), ISBN 0-8129-0721-3, p. 328</ref> The current version of the logo debuted in 1986 and has six feathers (yellow, orange, red, purple, blue, green).
In 1956, John J. Graham created an abstraction of an eleven-feathered [[peacock logo]] for American broadcaster [[NBC]]. This brightly hued peacock was adopted due to the increase in color programming. NBC's first color broadcasts showed only a still frame of the colorful peacock. The emblem made its first on-air appearance on May 22, 1956.<ref>The New York Times Encyclopedia of Television by Les Brown (Times Books, a division of Quadrangle/The New York Times Book Company, Inc., 1977), ISBN 0-8129-0721-3, p. 328</ref> The current version of the logo debuted in 1986 and has six feathers (yellow, orange, red, purple, blue, green).
